prefix: Approach the following question the way someone in high school would.
problem_prompt: Approach the following question the way someone in high school would. How many different counting numbers will each leave a remainder of 5 when divided into 47?
solution:
For a number to leave a remainder of 5 when divided into 47, it must satisfy two conditions:

1. it must divide exactly into $47 - 5$, or 42, and

2. it must be greater than 5, because the divisor is always greater than the remainder.

We list all divisors of 42 in pairs. They are 1 and 42, 2 and 21, 3 and 14, 6 and 7. Of these, only 42, 21, 14, 6, and 7 are greater than 5. There are $\boxed{5}$ different counting numbers that will leave a remainder of 5 when divided into 47.
gpt_response:
In high school, when we are dividing numbers we usually look at the remainder. In this case, we want to find out how many different counting numbers will leave a remainder of 5 when divided into 47.

To figure this out, we need to think about the factors of 42 (47-5=42) because when we divide 47 by any of the factors of 42, we will get a remainder of 5.

The factors of 42 are 1, 2, 3, 6, 7, 14, 21, and 42. So there are 8 different counting numbers that will leave a remainder of 5 when divided into 47.
solution_prompt:
Yes or no, is the final solution obtained in the following equal to 5?: In high school, when we are dividing numbers we usually look at the remainder. In this case, we want to find out how many different counting numbers will leave a remainder of 5 when divided into 47.

To figure this out, we need to think about the factors of 42 (47-5=42) because when we divide 47 by any of the factors of 42, we will get a remainder of 5.

The factors of 42 are 1, 2, 3, 6, 7, 14, 21, and 42. So there are 8 different counting numbers that will leave a remainder of 5 when divided into 47.
gpt_response_correct_incorrect: No. The final solution is not 5, it is 8.
